Award.AwardTitle: UNC Charlotte Planning Grant: IUCRC for Center for Visual and Decision Informatics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This planning grant will lay the foundation for establishing a successful IUCRC site at University of North Carolina - Charlotte, affiliated with the existing IUCRC center - the Center for Visual and Decision Informatics (CVDI). The UNC Charlotte site will focus on establishing, promoting, and disseminating best practices for research, development, and application of big data-driven analysis of risk management and mitigation in sustainable societies (social good) and regional industries, including financial services, healthcare, energy, and retail. The site will use the existing UNC Charlotte big data repository and analytics tools framework, called SOPHI, to establish a computational platform for corporations, governments, and universities to jointly address the issue of risk management and mitigation through the use of data, analytics, actionable policies, and verifiable outcomes.

The diversity of businesses around the Charlotte region has proven to be of interest to a diverse group
of students. With the existing graduate programs in analytics already more diverse than other UNC Charlotte
STEM graduate programs achieving 40% women enrollment, the PIs aim to attract underrepresented groups into the IUCRC activities and analytics programs on campus, both to augment those programs and to offer these students enhanced career opportunities in sought-after disciplines. As part of the award activities, the PIs will create a strategy and assign responsibilities for all aspects of this process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of the NSF's funding through the IUCRC program, UNC Charlotte successfuly organized a Planning Workshop on February 6th and 7th, 2017. This was the necessary step toward the development of a full proposal to join the existing Center for the Visual and Decision Informatics (CVDI) in its Phase II. The CVDI was established in February 2012 by the University of Louisiana at Lafayette and Drexel University. The Center focuses on developing advanced visual and decision support tools and techniques that enable decision makers to improve the way organizations’ information is interpreted and exploited. The CVDI has expanded recently, with Finland’s Tampere University of Technology joining the Center in 2015 and the University of Virginia and Stony Brook University following the suit in 2017.

The Planning Workshop at UNC Charlotte focused on data science and big data analytics research in understanding risks related to financial services, healthcare, energy (electricity producing and distribution), and social good. The first three sectors are the mainstay of Charlotte’s economy. Social good is the key issue currently facing the Charlotte community. In 2013, a national study was released that declared Charlotte at the bottom of the 50 largest US cities in terms of economic mobility. The city has completed a review outlining the reasons for this state of affairs. Social good analytics can aid the community’s effort to improve living conditions of its citizens, which will positively influence the workforce readiness for the employers.

The Planning Workshop attracted 25 industry, nonprofit, and local government representatives, as well as over 20 University faculty and students. It featured 18 proposed projects that addressed issues ranging from cyber security, sustainability, mobile health, and civic participation to healthy behaviors, visualization of virus geographic progression, and human trafficking. The Workshop succeeded in fostering a greater level of collaboration between industry, government, non-profits, and the University. The workshop eventually resulted in an industry-supported full proposal to the NSF to join CVDI's Phase II as the UNC Charlotte CVDI Site.

If approved, the UNC Charlotte CVDI Site’s research will complement the existing CVDI big data analytics and visualization research efforts and their applications to energy (oil), financial sector, healthcare, cyber security, homeland security, and Internet of things application domains.
